choices.text: Mycobacterium chelonae
Mycobacterium fortuitum
Mycobacterium abscessus
Mycobacterium kansasii

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with a worsening productive cough and weight loss. A sputum sample grows acid-fast bacilli that are identified as a rapidly growing atypical mycobacterium. Which organism is most likely responsible for his lung infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mycobacterium abscessus

 

Option C:

 

Mycobacterium abscessus is a rapidly growing non-tuberculous mycobacterium that is emerging as an important pathogen in lung infections, particularly in individuals with underlying lung diseases such as COPD. It is often resistant to conventional antibiotics, making it a challenging pathogen to treat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium chelonae: Incorrect because, although it is a rapidly growing mycobacterium, it is more commonly associated with skin and soft tissue infections.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium fortuitum: Incorrect as it is also more commonly associated with skin and post-surgical infections.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium kansasii: Incorrect because it typically causes slowly progressive lung disease that mimics tuberculosis, and it is not classified as a rapidly growing mycobacterium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium abscessus is a rapidly growing non-tuberculous mycobacterium that can cause lung infections, especially in patients with pre-existing pulmonary conditions.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p295, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1229-30,20/e p1267- 1268

choices.text: Mycobacterium intracellulare
Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Mycobacterium leprae
Mycobacterium kansasii

questions.text: A patient with a long history of smoking and chronic lung disease is diagnosed with a mycobacterial infection. The organism isolated is resistant to conventional tuberculosis medications and is commonly referred to by another name in clinical practice. Which of the following mycobacteria is known colloquially as "Battey bacillus"?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycobacterium intracellulare

 

Option A:

 

Mycobacterium intracellulare, along with Mycobacterium avium, is part of the Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) and is often resistant to standard anti-tuberculous drugs. It is sometimes referred to as "Battey bacillus" in Ref:   to its identification in a large number of patients at the Battey State Hospital in Georgia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Incorrect because it is the primary pathogen causing tuberculosis and is not referred to as Battey bacillus.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae: Incorrect as it is the causative agent of leprosy, not commonly resistant to tuberculosis medications.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium kansasii: Incorrect because, although it causes tuberculosis-like disease, it is not known as Battey bacillus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium intracellulare is part of the MAC and recognize its historical nickname "Battey bacillus," reflecting its clinical importance in certain patient populations.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p295, Ananthanarayan 9/e p360, 10/e p367

choices.text: Multibacillary leprosy is defined by the presence of more than five skin lesions.
The new case detection rate is an indicator of the incidence of leprosy.
The target elimination of leprosy is defined as a prevalence of less than 1 case per 10,000 population.
A patient who has not taken treatment for more than 6 months is classified as a defaulter.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing data on a regional leprosy control program. Which of the following statements regarding leprosy is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A patient who has not taken treatment for more than 6 months is classified as a defaulter.

 

Option D:

 

A patient who has not taken treatment for more than 6 months is classified as a defaulter.

 

A patient is classified as defaulter if the scheduled 6-month treatment for PB leprosy is not completed in 9 months and 12-month treatment for MB leprosy is not completed in 18 months. 

 

WHO recommendations as multidrug therapy (MDT) for treatment of leprosy

 

  • Recommended drugs: Dapsone, rifampicin and clofazimine
  • Alternate drugs: Ethionamide, quinolones (ofloxacin), minocycline and clarithromycin.
  • WHO 3 drug Regimen (2018)
     
    •  Dapsone (100 mg) is given daily, self-administered
    • Rifampicin (600 mg) is given once a month under supervision
    • Clofazimine (300 mg) is given once a month under supervision, and by 50 mg daily, self-administered
       

Duration of treatment—6 months for paucibacillary leprosy and 12 months for multibacillary leprosy. Follow-up is conducted annually for 2 years for paucibacillary leprosy and for five years for multibacillary leprosy.

 

Note: Earlier to 2018, clofazimine was given only for multibacillary leprosy. Many countries are yet to adopt the new WHO regimen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multibacillary leprosy is defined by the presence of more than five skin lesions: Correct, as this is the WHO's classification for multibacillary leprosy.

 

Option B. The new case detection rate is an indicator of the incidence of leprosy: Correct, as it represents the number of new cases detected during a specific period and serves as an incidence measure.

 

Option C. The target elimination of leprosy is defined as a prevalence of less than 1 case per 10,000 population: Correct, as this is the WHO's target for leprosy elimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Because of risk of development of drug resistance to single drug, WHO recommends multidrug therapy (MDT) for treatment of leprosy.

 

Ref:  Park 23/e p323, 24/e p336

choices.text: Causes Pontiac fever and Legionnaires' disease
Requires cysteine and iron for growth on artificial media
Is an obligate intracellular pathogen
Is transmitted via aerosols from environmental water sources

questions.text: During an epidemiological study of Legionnaires' disease, which of the following characteristics is incorrectly associated with Legionella pneumophila?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Is an obligate intracellular pathogen

 

Option C:

 

While Legionella pneumophila is capable of intracellular growth within amoebae and human macrophages, it is not an obligate intracellular pathogen as it can be cultured on artificial media (BCYE agar) in laboratory settings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Legionella pneumophila is the causative agent of both Pontiac fever and Legionnaires' disease.

 

Option B: It does require cysteine and iron for growth, which is why BCYE agar is used.

 

Option D: Transmission of Legionella pneumophila is through inhalation of aerosolized water droplets from environmental water sources, not person-to-person contact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Legionella pneumophila is not an obligate intracellular pathogen, as it can be cultured on artificial media (BCYE agar) in laboratory settings. This distinction is important when studying and diagnosing Legionnaires' disease.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p366-67, 2/e p379-380

choices.text: Campylobacteriosis in humans is induced mainly by campylobacter jejuni.
Poultry is a major source of infection
Humans are the reservoir of infection.
Guillain-Barre syndrome is a sequelae of campylobacter infection

questions.text: The following statements are true for Campylobacter except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Humans are the reservoir of infection

 

Option C:

 

Campylobacteriosis in humans is primarily induced by Campylobacter jejuni.  Poultry, especially undercooked chicken, is a major source of Campylobacter infection . Humans are not the reservoir of infection; Campylobacter species typically exist in the intestinal tracts of birds (especially poultry) and can contaminate food and water sources. Guillain-Barre syndrome is a known sequela of Campylobacter infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Campylobacteriosis in humans is induced mainly by campylobacter jejuni. 

 

Option B: Poultry is a major source of infection 

 

Option D: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a sequelae of campylobacter infection 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Humans are not the reservoir of Campylobacter infection; rather, Campylobacter species typically exist in the intestinal tracts of birds, especially poultry. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p361-62, 2/e p376-377, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1058-59, 20/e p1184

choices.text: CVA medium
Skirrow medium
Campylobacter blood agar
Schaedler’s agar and Regan-Lowe medium

questions.text: The appropriate culture media for Campylobacter are:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skirrow medium

 

Option B:

 

Campylobacter species have specific growth requirements, and the culture media listed are commonly used for their isolation and identification.

 

 

Figure: Campylobacter—A. Gram-negative spiral rods;B. Growth on Skirrow's media

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: CVA medium (Charcoal-Cefoperazone-Deoxycholate Agar) is a selective medium that inhibits the growth of competing bacteria and allows Campylobacter to thrive.

 

Option C: Campylobacter blood agar is a specialized agar containing blood and antibiotics that supports the growth of Campylobacter organisms.

 

Option D: Schaedler’s agar and Regan-Lowe medium are not typically used for the isolation of Campylobacter species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skirrow medium is often utilized for the isolation and identification of Campylobacter species, owing to their unique growth requirements.
  • Alternatives include the CVA medium (Charcoal-Cefoperazone-Deoxycholate Agar), which selectively inhibits competing bacteria, fostering an environment conducive to Campylobacter growth. 
  • Campylobacter blood agar, another specialized medium, incorporates blood and antibiotics to support these organisms. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p361-62, 2/e p376-377

choices.text: Culture on TCBS medium incubated at 37°C under aerobic conditions
Culture on Skirrow’s medium incubated at 42°C under micro-aerophilic conditions.
Culture on MacConkey medium incubated at 42°C under anaerobic conditions
Culture on Wilson and Blair’s medium incubated at 37°C under micro-aerophilic conditions

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of abdominal cramps along with profuse diarrhea. The treating physician wants to process the stool specimen for isolation of Campylobacter jejuni. Which of the following is the method of choice for the culture of stool?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Culture on Skirrow’s medium incubated at 42°C under micro-aerophilic conditions.

 

Option B:

 

The method of choice for the culture of stool specimens for Campylobacter jejuni is to use Skirrow's medium, which is selective for Campylobacter species. Campylobacter organisms grow best at a higher temperature (42°C) and under reduced oxygen levels (micro-aerophilic conditions). Skirrow's medium contains antibiotics that inhibit the growth of other bacteria, allowing Campylobacter to thrive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Suggests using TCBS (Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose) medium, which is typically used for Vibrio species, not Campylobacter.

 

Option C: Mentions MacConkey medium, which is a general-purpose medium and not selective for Campylobacter.

 

Option D: Mentions Wilson and Blair’s medium, which is used for the isolation of Brucella species, not Campylobacter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the isolation of Campylobacter jejuni from stool specimens, it is important to use a selective medium like Skirrow's medium, which provides the appropriate growth conditions (42°C and micro-aerophilic conditions) and inhibits the growth of other bacteria, allowing for the isolation of Campylobacter.

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p361-62, 2/e p376-377, Ananthanarayan 9/e p399, 10/e p406
